description: From Middle English mountayne, mountain, montaigne, from Anglo-Norman muntaine, muntaigne, from early Medieval Latin montÄnia, a collective based on Latin montem (â€œmountainâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *monti (compare Welsh mynydd (â€œmountainâ€), Albanian mat (â€œbank, shoreâ€), Avestan ğ¬¨ğ¬€ğ¬™ğ¬Œâ€ (mati, â€œpromontoryâ€)), from *men- (â€œto project, stick outâ€). Displaced native Old English beorg and dÅ«n, and partially displaced non-native Old English munt, from Latin mÅns (whence English mount).

entries.meaning: (countable) An elevation of land of considerable dimensions rising more or less abruptly, forming a conspicuous figure in the landscape, usually having a small extent of surface at its summit. [from 12th c.]
examples: Everest is the highest mountain in the world.
We spent the weekend hiking in the mountains.

entries.meaning: (countable) Something very large in size or quantity; a huge amount; a great heap. [from 15th c.]
examples: He was a real mountain of a man, standing seven feet tall.
There's still a mountain of work to do.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, now historical) Wine from Malaga made from grapes that grow on a mountain. [from 18th c.]
examples: Called on Courtenay, with whom I walked to Hampstead Heath, and got into excellent spirits, enjoying fine fresh air; then dined with him tÃªte-a-tÃªte on mutton broth and mackerel and drank mountain and old port moderately.
